Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Story: I stared at my phone, the family group chat lighting up with messages about our annual holiday trip. My mom’s text was clear: “We really want you there this year. It’s important.” I could almost hear her voice, hopeful and a little pleading. As a sister, I knew how much these gatherings meant, how my absence would be noticed and quietly mourned. But at the same time, my work headset buzzed in my ear. The call queue was endless, and management had just sent another reminder: “Breaks must be taken as scheduled. No exceptions.” They were tracking every minute, and I’d already been warned about stepping away outside my allotted time. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectation to be present for my family against the rigid demands of my job. I felt pulled in two directions, guilt and anxiety twisting together. I wanted to be a good sister, but I also needed this job. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between replying to my family and logging my next break, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
